LEVOCARNITINE

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Renal impairment
  • Side effects
  • Cautions
  • Monitoring requirements
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Primary carnitine deficiency due to inborn errors of metabolism,

By slow intravenous injection

  • For adults
    Up to 200 mg/kg daily in 2–4 divided doses; maximum 3 g per day.
  • For adults
    Up to 100 mg/kg daily in 2–4 divided doses, to be administered over 2–3 minutes.

Secondary cartinine deficiency in haemodialysis patients,

Initially by slow intravenous injection

  • For adults
    20 mg/kg, to be administered over 2–3 minutes, after each dialysis session, dosage adjusted according to plasma-carnitine concentration, then (by mouth) maintenance 1 g daily, administered if benefit is gained from first intravenous course.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Appropriate to use; no evidence of teratogenicity in animal studies.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Accumulation of metabolites may occur with chronic oral administration in severe impairment.

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Abdominal pain, body odour, diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting,

Side-effects may be dose-related—monitor tolerance during first week and after any dose increase.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Diabetes mellitus

Monitoring requirements

Therapeutic drug monitoring

Monitoring of free and acyl carnitine in blood and urine recommended.

Prepared medicinal forms of LEVOCARNITINE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: capsule,
Tablet
Chewable tablet
Capsule
Oral solution
Solution for injection
